abstract.text: The STAR experiment at the Relativistic Heavy-Ion Collider at Brookhaven National Laboratory is carrying out a spin physics program in high-energy polarized p + p collisions at √ s = 200 − 500 GeV to gain a deeper insight into the spin structure and dynamics of the proton.

One of the main objectives of the spin physics program at RHIC is the extraction of the polarized gluon distribution function based on measurements of gluon initiated processes, such as hadron and jet production.
The STAR detector is well suited for the reconstruction of various final states involving jets, π 0 , π ± , e ± and γ, which allows to measure several different processes.
Recent results will be shown on the measurement of jet production and hadron production at √ s = 200 GeV.
The RHIC spin physics program has recently completed the first data taking period in 2009 of polarized p+ p collisions at √ s = 500 GeV.
This opens a new era in the study of the spin-flavor structure of the proton based on the production of W −(+) bosons.
Recent STAR results on the first measurement of W boson production in polarized p + p collisions will be shown.

body_text.text: Introduction
The spin structure and dynamics of the nucleon is one of the fundamental and unresolved questions in Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Contrary to atomic physics where the total angular momentum of an atom can be accounted for by basic quantum theory in terms of its underlying atomic constituents, a complete theoretical description of the proton spin decomposed in terms of contributions from quark and gluon angular momenta and spins is still missing.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Various experimental programs have been conducted in the past to deepen our understanding on the proton spin.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Deep-inelastic scattering (DIS) experiments have clearly established that the quark spin contribution is small and accounts for only ≈ 25% of the proton spin [1,2].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: High energy polarized p + p collisions at √ s = 200 − 500 GeV at RHIC provide a unique way to probe the proton spin structure and dynamics using hard scattering processes [3].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The production of jets and hadrons is the prime focus of the gluon polarization studies.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The production of W −(+) bosons at √ s = 500 GeV provides an ideal tool to study the spin-flavor structure of the proton.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This has been pointed out at the very early design stages of the polarized proton collider program at RHIC [4].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The first global analysis of polarized DIS data, as well as results obtained by the PHENIX [5] and STAR [6] experiments in polarized p + p collisions at RHIC placed a strong constraint on the gluon spin contribution in the gluon momentum range of 0.05 < x < 0.2, and suggested that the gluon spin contribution is not large in that range [7].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Constraining the polarized gluon arXiv:1004.4884v1 [hep-ex]  distribution function, ∆g, through inclusive measurements has been, so far, the prime focus of the STAR physics analysis program of the Run 3/4 [8], Run 5 [6] and Run 6 [9] data samples.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Inclusive measurements, such as inclusive jet production, integrate over a fairly large x region for a given jet transverse momentum region.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: While those measurements provide a strong constraint on the value of ∆g integrated over a range in x, those measurements do not permit a direct sensitivity to the actual x dependence.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This motivates the need for correlation measurements in polarized p + p collisions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The STAR collaboration has presented a first measurement of the longitudinal spin transfer D LL in inclusive Λ (Λ → pπ − ) andΛ (Λ →pπ + ) production in polarized proton-proton collisions at a center-of-mass energy of √ s = 200 GeV [10].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This measurement may provide constraints on strange (anti) quark polarization [11] and can yield new insight into polarized fragmentation functions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The first data taking period in 2009 of polarized p + p collisions at √ s = 500 GeV opens a new era in the study of the spin-flavor structure of the proton based on the production of W −(+) bosons.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: W −(+) bosons are produced predominantly throughū + d (u +d) collisions and can be detected through their leptonic decay.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Quark and anti-quark helicity distribution functions are probed at large scales set by the mass of the W boson (Q ∼ m W ) where theoretical calculations are well under control.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The theoretical framework is well developed to describe the production of W bosons in high-energy polarized p + p collisions including the description of the W decay leptons subject to experimental cuts, such as the transverse momentum p T and pseudo-rapidity η of the final-state leptons [12,13].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This development profits from a rich history of hadroproduction of weak bosons at the CERN SPS and the FNAL Tevatron and provides a firm basis to use W production as a new high-energy probe in polarized p + p collisions [14].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The STAR Collaboration has provided critical measurements on the sudy of transverse spin effects in polarized p+ p collisions at RHIC.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: An overview of these results is discussed in a separate paper [15].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Recent jet A LL results

STAR reconstructs jets with the midpoint cone algorithm using clusters of charged track momenta measured with the STAR Time Projection Chamber (TPC) and tower energy deposits in the STAR Barrel Electromagnetic Calorimeter (BEMC) within a cone radius of R ≡ ∆η 2 + ∆φ 2 [9].
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: The jet sample was required to be within a fiducial range of −0.7 < η Detector < 0.9 for the 2006 data sample with a cone radius of R = 0.7.
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: The dominant fraction of jet events in the 2006 data sample are based on a jet patch (JP) trigger that required a minimum energy deposition for a group of towers over a region of ∆η × ∆φ = 1.0 × 1.0.
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: This trigger was taken in coincidence with a minimum-bias condition using the STAR Beam-Beam Counter (BBC).
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: Throughout the following discussion, four gluon polarization scenarios have been used as input to NLO perturbative QCD calculations of A LL .
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: The GRSV standard case refers to a global analysis fit of polarized DIS data [16].
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: The case for a vanishing gluon polarization (GRSV-ZERO) and the case of a maximally positive (GRSV-MAX) or negative (GRSV-MIN) gluon polarization have also been considered.
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: The GS-C [17] set of ∆g is reflected by a large positive gluon polarization at low x, a node around x ∼ 0.1 and a negative gluon polarization at large x at a scale of Q 2 ∼ 1 GeV 2 .
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: Figure 1 shows the most recent STAR preliminary result of A LL for inclusive jet production as a function of p T based on the 2006 data sample of 4.7 pb −1 .
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: Typical beam polarization values during the 2006 data-taking period were 55 − 60%.
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: The leading systematic uncertainty comes from the trigger and jet reconstruction biases.
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: Differences between observed and true jet p T are estimated using PYTHIA and GEANT simulations and result in corrections being applied to the jet p T values.
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: Additionally, the trigger conditions at STAR can artificially bias the analyzed data  sample towards particular flavors of partonic collisions.
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: A conservative systematic uncertainty is evaluated to account for this effect which incorporates all allowable gluon polarization scenarios.
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: The A LL curves in Figure 1 are derived from NLO fits to world polarized DIS data by two separate theory groups, GRSV [16] and GS [17].
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: The currently measured result is consistent with a small gluon polarization scenario for the STAR x-range of 0.03 < x < 0.3.
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: This x-range accounts for ∼ 50% of the total ∆G integral, i.e. ∆G = 1 0 ∆gdx, for GRSV-STD.
body_text.section: Recent jet A LL results

body_text.text: STAR Preliminary
Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results
Neutral pions are identified via the two-photon decay channel, which accounts for more than 98% of π 0 decays.
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: Two primary sub-detectors, the STAR Barrel Electromagnetic Calorimeter (BEMC) and respective Shower Maximum Detector (SMD) are employed to reconstruct decay photons from mid rapidity neutral pions.
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: Charged pion production is of particular interest since the difference of the longitudinal double-spin asymmetries for π + and π − production, A LL (π + ) -A LL (π − ), tracks the sign of ∆g, due to the opposite signs of the polarized distribution functions for up and down quarks.
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: The STAR Time Projection Chamber (TPC) offers robust reconstruction and identification of charged pions up to a transverse momentum of 15 GeV/c.
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: Particle identification is accomplished using measurements of ionization energy loss in the TPC.
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: Figure 2
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: (a) shows A LL for neutral pion production at mid rapidity as a function of p T based on the 2006 data sample [18].
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: This new measurement is shown in comparison to NLO calculations assuming different gluon polarization scenarios [9,18].
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: This measurement reaches to higher p T values compared to previous measurements by PHENIX [19] and STAR [20].
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: At the present level of precision, the data excludes extreme gluon polarization scenarios.
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: The STAR collaboration has recently presented also results for neutral pion production at forward rapidity based on the STAR Electromagnetic Endcap Calorimeter (EEMC) and the STAR Forward Pion Detector (FPD) [21].
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: These measurements provide an important milestone for future photon-jet coincidence measurements at STAR.
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: Figure 2
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: (b) and
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: (c) show STAR's new preliminary result of A LL for charged pion (π − and π + ) / jet correlation measurements at mid rapidity.
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: Charged pions are reconstructed opposite a jet that triggered the experiment.
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: The data are shown versus z ≡ p T (π)/p T (jet) and were obtained in 2006 [22].
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: Full NLO calculations for this observable have recently been released [23].
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: These calculations will provide the basis for charged pion results to be included in a global analysis.
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: The data shown for charged pion production are compared to a LO MC evaluation of A LL excluding extreme scenarios of ∆g.
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: The measurement of A LL (π + ) is of particular interest, since its analyzing power is large because of the large ug scattering contribution to the production cross section and sizable ∆u/u.
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: In the future, more precise measurements of A LL (π + ) have a great potential for providing a better understanding of ∆g.
body_text.section: Recent neutral and charged pion A LL results

body_text.text: Status and prospects of di-jet production
Correlation measurements such as those for di-jet production allow for a better constraint of the partonic kinematics and thus the shape of ∆g.
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: At LO, the di-jet invariant mass, M , is proportional to the product of the i.e. different η 3 /η 4 combinations, ranging from symmetric (x 1 = x 2 ) partonic collisions to asymmetric (x 1 < x 2 or x 1 > x 2 ) partonic collisions.
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: This, together with the variation of the center-of-mass energy, is expected to constrain ∆g over a wide range in x of approximately ∼ 2 • 10 −3 < x < 0.3 for di-jet and photon-jet events.
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: The NLO framework for correlation measurements exists and therefore those measurements can be used in a global analysis [24].
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: Figure 3 shows a comparison of STAR 2005 di-jet data and a PYTHIA Monte-Carlo simulation with the yield at the top and the ratio at the bottom for the invariant mass M , the pseudo-rapidity sum η 3 + η 4 and the cosine of the partonic center-of-mass scattering angle cos θ * determined from the pseudo-rapidities of both final-state jets.
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: The normalization between data and Monte-Carlo is fixed by the invariant mass distributions.
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: The same normalization factor is then applied to both other di-jet distributions.
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: Data and Monte-Carlo are found to be in good agreement.
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: Figure 4
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: (a) shows the statistical precision of the longitudinal double-spin asymmetry, A LL , as a function of the di-jet invariant mass, M .
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: Those uncertainties, extracted from the 2006 data sample, are compared to a LO MC evaluation of A LL computed with a PYTHIA MC sample using different event weights to account for different polarized gluon distribution functions of GRSV [16] and DSSV [7].
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: The size of the statistical uncertainty at the highest invariant mass bin is at the level of the difference between GRSV-STD and DSSV.
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: Asymmetric cuts are imposed for the LO MC and the NLO determination of min(p T ) ≥ 7 GeV/c and max(p T ) ≥ 10 GeV/c.

body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: Good agreement is found between a LO MC evaluation of A LL and a full NLO calculation.
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: Scale uncertainties are found to be small in comparison to the variation of the chosen polarized gluon distribution functions, in particular, at large values of M .
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: While inclusive measurements from STAR have provided important constraints on ∆g, and will continue to do so, the impact of correlation measurements to the x dependence should greatly enhance our understanding of ∆g.
body_text.section: Status and prospects of di-jet production

body_text.text: Measurement of W boson production at STAR
The data used for the first W boson production analysis at STAR were collected in 2009 colliding polarized proton beams at 250 GeV.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The STAR detector systems used in this analysis are the STAR Time Projection Chamber (TPC), the STAR Barrel Electromagnetic Calorimeter (BEMC) and STAR Electromagnetic Endcap Calorimeter (EEMC).
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: Only their tower response has been taken into account in this analysis.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The BEMC was used to measure the transverse energy, E T , of e ± .
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The suppression of the QCD background by several orders of magnitude was based on the TPC, BEMC and EEMC.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: Figure 5 shows event displays from the 2009 data taking period for a W candidate event (a), a Z 0 candidate event and a di-jet candidate event (c).
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: A lego plot is shown in Figure 6 displaying the BEMC E T and the TPC p T distribution for a W candidate event at the top and a di-jet candidate event at the bottom.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: Proton-proton collision events focusing on W production at √ s = 500 were identified by a two-step energy requirement in the BEMC.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: Electrons and positrons from W production at mid rapidity are characterized by large E T peaked at ∼ M W /2 (Jacobian peak).
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: At the hardware trigger level (L0), a high tower (HT) calorimetric trigger condition required E T > 7.3 GeV in a single BEMC tower.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: At the software trigger level (L2), a dedicated trigger algorithm was developed that required that a 2 × 2 tower cluster E T sum exceeds 13 GeV.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The offline selection of W candidate events is based on kinematical and topological difference between leptonic W ± decays, and QCD background events as shown in Figure 5 and Figure 6. Events from W ± → e ± + ν decays contain a nearly isolated e ± with a neutrino in the opposite direction in azimuth.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The neutrino escapes detection, leading to a large missing energy.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: is sketched by the black dashed rectangular region.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The TPC high-p T entry appears in the same η − φ region as the large BEMC E T entry.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: Both BEMC SMD layers show a large energy deposition at the same location in the η − φ plane as the TPC high-p T and the BEMC high-E T entry.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: An electron candidate is defined to be any TPC track with p T > 10 GeV/c that is associated with a primary vertex with |z| < 100 cm, where z is the distance along the beam direction.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: A 2 × 2 BEMC tower cluster E T sum is required to be larger than 15 GeV.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The excess BEMC E T sum in a 4 × 4 tower cluster centered around the respective 2 × 2 tower cluster is required to be below 5%.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: In addition, the distance between the 2 × 2 cluster tower centroid and the TPC track is required to be less than 7 cm.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: A near-cone is formed around the electron candidate direction with a radius in η-φ space of R = 0.7.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The excess BEMC and TPC E T sum is required to be less than 12% of the 2 × 2 cluster E T .
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The away side requirement is based on a cut on the BEMC and TPC E T sum to be less than 8 GeV.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: This sum is extended over the full η range of the BEMC and EEMC and ∆φ = 0.7 as shown in Figure 7. Figure 8 shows the evolution of all cuts for the BEMC 2 × 2 E T distribution.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: A clear Jacobian peak emerges characteristic for W production in contrast to QCD background dominating the low E T region.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: A data-driven procedure was applied to estimate the level of QCD background events.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The first part consists of an estimate of the impact of the missing calorimeter coverage for −2 < η < −1 on the cluster E T distribution.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: This estimate was obtained by performing a parallel analysis without the EEMC as an active detector.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The difference in yield of accepted events as a function of E T provides an absolute estimate for the missing calorimetric coverage.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The remaining background is estimated by fitting a separate QCD shape distribution in E T to the region of E T < 19 GeV shown as the black histogram in Figure 9.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The fitted QCD background distribution is shown by the blue histogram in Figure 9.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: The background subtracted distribution is shown by the yellow histogram.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: Figure 9 also shows the distribution from a PYTHIA Monte-Carlo simulation.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: Good agreement in yield and shape is found between the data and Monte-Carlo distribution for the charge-sum BEMC E T distribution.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: Reconstructed BEMC lepton transverse energy for W events.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: effort has been performed on the TPC calibration to allow a full charge-sign separation.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: This and in particular the first measurement of the respective charge-separated cross-sections and parity-violating singe-spin asymmetries A L at mid rapidity will be discussed in a forthcoming publication.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR

body_text.text: Future planned high-statistics measurements at forward and backward pseudo-rapidities will focus on constraining the polarization ofd andū quarks, respectively to deepen our understanding of the spin structure of the QCD sea.
body_text.section: Measurement of W boson production at STAR
